claim_reports.claim_text: The amount of CO2 in the atmosphere has increased by more than a third since the Industrial Revolution.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence overwhelmingly supports the claim that CO2 levels in the atmosphere have increased by more than a third since the Industrial Revolution, with multiple high-reliability sources confirming an increase of over 50% from pre-industrial levels.

supports.title: Carbon Dioxide - Earth Indicator - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere has increased by more than 50% since the start of industrial times in the 18th century, which is significantly more than a third, thus supporting the claim.
supports.snippet: With a more than 50% increase in CO2 since the start of industrial times in the 18th century, scientific measurements have linked this increase ...

supports.title: Climate change: atmospheric carbon dioxide
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that atmospheric carbon dioxide has increased by more than 50% since the start of the Industrial Revolution, confirming that the amount of CO2 in the atmosphere has indeed risen by more than a third since that time.
supports.snippet: Atmospheric carbon dioxide is now 50 percent higher than it was before the Industrial Revolution. ... since the start of the Industrial Revolution in 1750.

supports.title: Evidence - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that atmospheric carbon dioxide levels have increased significantly since the Industrial Revolution, with a noted rise from about 280 ppm in 1750 to over 422 ppm in recent years, indicating an increase of more than a third.
supports.snippet: ... atmospheric CO2 has increased since the Industrial Revolution. Luthi ... 1800s, and is proceeding at a rate not seen over many recent millennia.

supports.title: Carbon dioxide now more than 50% higher than pre-industrial levels
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere have increased by more than 50% since the start of the Industrial Revolution, confirming that CO2 levels are now 150% of what they were in 1750. This supports the claim that CO2 has increased by more than a third since that time.
supports.snippet: Prior to the Industrial Revolution, CO2 levels were consistently around 280 ppm for almost 6,000 years of human civilization. Since then, ...

supports.title: The History of Carbon Dioxide Emissions | World Resources Institute
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that atmospheric carbon dioxide levels have significantly increased since the Industrial Revolution, with current levels being over 424 ppm, which is more than a third higher than pre-industrial levels.
supports.snippet: From 1850 to the mid-20th century, the world experienced near-constant growth in emissions. This was due largely to industrialization and ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Atmospheric carbon dioxide hasn't reached today's levels in hundreds of thousands of years.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence presents a mixed view on the claim that atmospheric carbon dioxide hasn't reached today's levels in hundreds of thousands of years. While NASA indicates that current levels are significantly higher than those in the past, several other high-reliability sources support the claim that today's CO2 levels have not been seen in that timeframe. However, NOAA's data remains unclear, adding to the complexity of the assessment.

refutes.title: Carbon Dioxide - Earth Indicator - NASA Science
refutes.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that current atmospheric carbon dioxide levels are significantly higher than those observed in the past, particularly since the start of the industrial era, suggesting that today's levels have not been reached in hundreds of thousands of years.
refutes.snippet: The amount of carbon dioxide in Earth's atmosphere has increased sharply in the past 100 years as measured from the ground and from satellites.

supports.title: Climate change: atmospheric carbon dioxide
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that current atmospheric carbon dioxide levels are significantly higher than those observed at the end of the last ice age, suggesting that today's levels have not been reached in hundreds of thousands of years.
supports.snippet: In the past 60 years, carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has increased 100-200 times faster than it did during the end of the last ice age.

supports.title: A New 66 Million-Year History of Carbon Dioxide Offers Little ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that atmospheric CO2 levels have significantly increased in recent decades, reaching levels that are at least 1.5 times greater than those observed at the end of the last ice age, suggesting that current levels have not been seen in hundreds of thousands of years.
supports.snippet: Which does not change the simple facts that atmospheric CO2 was naturally cycling from about 200ppm to about 250ppm for the past million years.

supports.title: The Last Time CO2 Was This High, Humans Didn't Exist
supports.evidence_summary: The article states that CO2 levels are currently far higher than they have been for the past 800,000 years, indicating that today's levels have not been reached in that timeframe.
supports.snippet: CO2 levels are far higher now than they have been for anytime during the past 800,000 years. Click image to enlarge. Credit: Scripps Institution ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Human activities are driving up the earth's temperature and changing the world.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that human activities are driving up the earth's temperature and changing the world, with multiple high-reliability sources confirming that greenhouse gas emissions from human activities are the primary cause of global warming.

supports.title: Are humans causing or contributing to global warming? - Climate
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that human activities, particularly the emission of greenhouse gases, are significantly contributing to the increase in Earth's temperature and altering the climate.
supports.snippet: Yes, by increasing the abundance of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, human activities are amplifying Earth's natural greenhouse effect.

supports.title: Climate change: global temperature
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence clearly states that human activities, particularly through the emission of greenhouse gases, are the primary cause of the global warming trend observed since the mid-20th century, confirming the claim that human activities are driving up the earth's temperature and changing the world.
supports.snippet: Human activities, principally through emissions of greenhouse gases, have unequivocally caused global warming, with global surface temperature ...

supports.title: The Causes of Climate Change - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence clearly supports the claim that human activities are driving up the earth's temperature and changing the world, as it attributes the observed global warming trend since the mid-20th century to human expansion of the greenhouse effect, primarily through the burning of fossil fuels and deforestation.
supports.snippet: Human Activity Is the Cause of Increased Greenhouse Gas Concentrations. Over the last century, burning of fossil fuels like coal and oil has ...

supports.title: Human Impacts on the Environment: A Focus on Climate Change
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that human activities are causing significant changes in both terrestrial and aquatic environments, which supports the claim that these activities are driving up the earth's temperature and altering the world.
supports.snippet: Human activities are driving large scale changes in terrestrial and aquatic environments through pollution, water withdrawals, the hunting and harvesting of ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica are melting, causing sea levels to rise.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence overwhelmingly supports the claim that ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica are melting, contributing to sea level rise. Multiple high-reliability sources, including NASA and UCAR, confirm significant ice loss in both regions due to climate change, with Greenland losing approximately 266 billion tons and Antarctica about 135 billion tons of ice annually.

supports.title: Greenland's Ice Is Melting - UCAR Center for Science Education
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that ice sheets in Greenland are melting at an accelerated rate due to climate change, contributing significantly to sea level rise. The study indicates that Greenland's ice loss has increased dramatically, with extreme melting episodes becoming more frequent, which directly impacts global sea levels.
supports.snippet: Earth's warming climate means that overall Greenland loses more ice than it gains each year. Warmer temperatures mean more melt days. During summer, ...

supports.title: Ice sheet surface melt is accelerating in Greenland and slowing in ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica are melting due to rising temperatures, with Greenland losing about 266 billion tons and Antarctica losing about 135 billion tons of ice per year, contributing to sea level rise.
supports.snippet: Surface ice in Greenland has been melting at an increasing rate in recent decades, while the trend in Antarctica has moved in the opposite direction.

supports.title: Ice Sheets - Earth Indicator - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica are melting due to rising air and ocean temperatures, leading to significant contributions to sea level rise as the meltwater drains into the ocean.
supports.snippet: The animated map shows where ice melting occurred in Antarctica and Greenland from 2002-2023. Red and orange colors show where ice mass is ...

supports.title: Guest post: How the Greenland ice sheet fared in 2023 - Carbon Brief
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica are melting due to rising air and ocean temperatures, leading to significant contributions to sea level rise as the meltwater drains into the ocean.
supports.snippet: The Greenland ice sheet melt season 2023 saw very high melt but also higher than usual rain and snowfall in the late spring and early ...

supports.title: Six ways loss of Arctic ice impacts everyone - World Wildlife Fund
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that ice sheets in Greenland are melting at an accelerated rate due to climate change, contributing significantly to sea level rise and affecting global weather patterns. The study indicates that Greenland's melting ice is a major factor in rising sea levels, with extreme melting episodes becoming more frequent in recent decades.
supports.snippet: Discover six ways Arctic ice loss affects the planet, including rising sea levels, weather changes, and impacts on wildlife and communities.

supports.title: The Greenland Ice Sheet, Sea Level Rise, and Coastal Communities
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that ice sheets in Greenland are melting at an accelerated rate due to climate change, contributing significantly to sea level rise, with projections indicating that this trend will continue.
supports.snippet: The Greenland ice sheet alone has the potential to raise global sea levels by an astonishing 23 feet were it to melt away completely.

claim_reports.claim_text: The main cause of climate change is the greenhouse effect.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that the main cause of climate change is the greenhouse effect, as highlighted by NASA and NRDC, which explain how increased greenhouse gas emissions from human activities disrupt the energy balance and contribute to climate change.

supports.title: What is the greenhouse effect? - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence explains that the greenhouse effect, primarily driven by greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide, is crucial for maintaining Earth's temperature and that human activities have increased these gases, disrupting the energy balance and contributing to climate change.
supports.snippet: The greenhouse effect is the process through which heat is trapped near Earth's surface by substances known as 'greenhouse gases.

supports.title: Greenhouse Effect 101 - NRDC
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses emissions of carbon dioxide and methane from burning fossil fuels, which are key contributors to the greenhouse effect and thus climate change.
supports.snippet: These emissions, made up mostly of carbon dioxide and methane, stem primarily from burning natural gas and oil for heating and cooking, though ...

supports.title: Causes and Effects of Climate Change | United Nations
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that the greenhouse effect, primarily driven by greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide, is essential for maintaining Earth's temperature. However, it also emphasizes that human activities, particularly the burning of fossil fuels, have significantly increased greenhouse gas concentrations, leading to climate change.
supports.snippet: Fossil fuels – coal, oil and gas – are by far the largest contributor to global climate change, accounting for around 68 per cent of global greenhouse gas ...

supports.title: What is the greenhouse effect? - NASA Science
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that gases like carbon dioxide and methane trap heat in the atmosphere, as they are described as greenhouse gases that absorb and radiate heat, contributing to the greenhouse effect.
supports.snippet: The greenhouse effect is the process through which heat is trapped near Earth's surface by substances known as 'greenhouse gases.'

supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that gases like carbon dioxide and methane trap heat in the atmosphere by absorbing and radiating heat, which is a key aspect of the greenhouse effect.
supports.snippet: These "trace" gases contribute substantially to warming of the Earth's surface and atmosphere due to their abilities to contain the infrared radiation emitted ...

supports.snippet: Greenhouse gases warm the Earth by trapping heat near the surface. Heat-trapping greenhouse gases emitted by humans, mainly from burning fossil ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Exposure to higher levels of smog can cause health problems such as asthma and heart disease.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that exposure to higher levels of smog can cause health problems such as asthma and heart disease. High-reliability sources, including the NIH, AirNow.gov, and WHO, confirm that air pollution is linked to exacerbated asthma symptoms and increased risks of cardiovascular diseases.

supports.title: Air Pollution and Your Health
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that exposure to higher levels of air pollution, including smog, is linked to health issues such as asthma and heart disease, with studies indicating increased symptoms in asthma patients and a higher risk of heart attacks and strokes.
supports.snippet: Many studies have established that short-term exposure to higher levels of outdoor air pollution is associated with reduced lung function, asthma, cardiac ...

supports.title: Asthma and Heart Disease - AirNow.gov
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that exposure to air pollutants, including smog, can exacerbate asthma symptoms and trigger serious heart conditions such as heart attacks and strokes, particularly in vulnerable populations.
supports.snippet: Studies also show that air pollution can trigger heart attacks, stroke, and irregular heart rhythms—especially in people who are already at risk for these ...

supports.title: Health Impacts of Air Pollution - World Health Organization (WHO)
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that exposure to air pollution, particularly fine particulate matter (PM2.5), is linked to increased risks of cardiovascular disease and exacerbation of existing health conditions such as asthma. This supports the claim that higher levels of smog can cause health problems like asthma and heart disease.
supports.snippet: Exposure to high levels of particulate matter, for example, can lead to reduced lung function, respiratory infections and aggravated asthma from short-term ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Climate change can directly affect people's physical health by increasing smog levels.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources, including a PubMed Central article and WHO reports, consistently indicate that climate change exacerbates air pollution, particularly smog, which directly impacts respiratory health. This strong consensus supports the claim that climate change can affect physical health by increasing smog levels.

supports.title: Climate change, air quality, and respiratory health - PubMed Central
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses how climate change can intensify air pollution, particularly by altering the physicochemical properties of particulate matter, which can lead to increased deposition of these particles in the lungs and subsequently heighten the risk of respiratory diseases.
supports.snippet: In conclusion, climate change can affect particle deposition in the lungs by influencing air quality, particularly in terms of particulate ...

supports.title: How climate change exacerbates air pollution (and its health impacts)
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that climate change can intensify air pollution, particularly by altering the physicochemical properties of particulate matter, which increases the risk of respiratory diseases. This directly supports the claim that climate change affects physical health through increased smog levels.
supports.snippet: About one-third of all particulate matter pollution in the United States now comes from wildfire smoke—wildfires that are more intense and ...

supports.title: Climate impacts of air pollution - World Health Organization (WHO)
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence discusses how climate change can intensify air pollution, particularly by altering the physicochemical properties of particulate matter, which can lead to increased respiratory health risks. This supports the claim that climate change can affect physical health by increasing smog levels.
supports.snippet: Lower levels of air pollution result in better cardiovascular and respiratory health of populations in both the long- and short-term. Reducing ambient and ...

This supports the claim that climate change can directly affect people's health by increasing smog levels.
supports.snippet: Potential increased risk of metabolic disorders, including glucose intolerance, hyperglycemia, and diabetes; ... Potential impact on the central nervous system, ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Warmer temperatures make weather more extreme, leading to intense storms and floods.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence supports the claim that warmer temperatures lead to more extreme weather, with NOAA and EDF indicating increased frequency and intensity of storms and floods due to climate change. However, NASA and USGS present an unclear perspective, suggesting that while warming affects weather patterns, the specific outcomes regarding extreme weather events remain uncertain.

supports.title: Climate change impacts - NOAA
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that as the climate changes, the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events, including storms and floods, are increasing due to rising greenhouse gas levels. This supports the claim that warmer temperatures lead to more extreme weather.

supports.snippet: As the storms travel across warm oceans, they pull in more water vapor and heat, adding more energy to the storm. That means heavier rainfall, stronger wind ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Replacing fossil fuels with renewable energy sources can help combat climate change.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that replacing fossil fuels with renewable energy sources can help combat climate change. Multiple high-reliability sources, including the NRDC and IRENA, emphasize that transitioning to renewable energy is critical for mitigating climate change and reducing reliance on fossil fuels.

transcript_data.text: human activities from pollution to overpopulation are driving up the earth's temperature and fundamentally changing the world around us the main cause is a phenomenon known as the greenhouse effect gases in the atmosphere such as water vapor carbon dioxide methane nitrous oxide and chlorofluorocarbons let the sun's light in but keep some of the heat from escaping like the glass walls of a greenhouse the more greenhouse gases in the atmosphere the more heat gets trapped strengthening the greenhouse effect and increasing the earth's temperature human activities like the burning of fossil fuels have increased the amount of co2 in the atmosphere by more than a third since the Industrial Revolution the rapid increase in greenhouse gases in the atmosphere has warmed the planet at an alarming rate while Earth's climate has fluctuated in the past atmospheric carbon dioxide hasn't reached today's levels in hundreds of thousands of years climate change has consequences for our oceans our weather our food sources and our health ice sheets such as Greenland and Antarctica are melting the extra water that was once held in glaciers causes sea levels to rise and spills out of the oceans flooding coastal regions warmer temperatures also make weather more extreme this means not only more intense major storms floods and heavy snowfall but also longer and more frequent droughts these changes in weather pose challenges growing crops becomes more difficult the areas where plants and animals can live shift and water supplies are diminished in addition to creating new agricultural challenges climate change can directly affect people's physical health in urban areas the warmer atmosphere creates an environment that traps and increases the amount of smog this is because smog contains ozone particles which increase rapidly at higher temperatures exposure to higher levels of smog can cause health problems such as asthma heart disease and lung cancer while the rapid rate of climate change is caused by humans humans are also the ones who can combat it if we work to replace fossil fuels with renewable energy sources like solar and wind which don't produce greenhouse gas emissions we might still be able to prevent some of the worst effects of climate change [Music] you
